column4: The requested URL /~user/test1.html was not found on this server. <---> Apache/2.0.50 (Ubuntu) Server at localhost Port 80

Apache/2.0.50 (Ubuntu) Server at localhost Port 80
Got it
It's working
Now - should I try a php file..
Just for heck of it
Now . . . who's gonna help me?! Come on . . . someone with php/apache/linux/LAMP knowledge.. step right up
Depends. :-)

You're on. Alright . . . so uhh, I wanted to get LAMP working.. did so, at one point.. had installed Apache 1.3, php4, mysql . . . and everything seemed to work great together . . . then I saw apache2 was available . . . did a complete removal of everything, and installed everything again.. apache2, php4, mysql . . . now apache2 works, but not php . . . where to begin?
You're beyond me there.  I've not touched Apache 2 yet.  Seen no reason to.
Thank you anyways for the mere attempt (really) :D
I've not gone to Apache 2 yet for exactly the problems you're having. Apache 1.3 works plenty good enough.
Suppose I install apache1.3.. and do leave apache2 as is - will this linger problems? Or shall I just do it?
Once again, I have no experience.
But if it were me, I'd stick to Apache 1.3. :-)

For what inducement? Quiet honestly . . . the mere reason I had gone to apache2 was . . . well, because the number '2' was higher than the number '1.3,' and higher numbers are usually more dependable in today's world
I know that attitude all too well. :-)
No, there should be no conflicts.  And you can run them both at the same time, on different ports.
Different ports... will I have to put that manually? Or will synaptic do that for me? :x
For what you're talking about, it's all done by hand.
:( . . . I'll do it, I've come this far (although by clicking "yes" and "next") . . . but I wanna get to know php.. I'll do it!
